conversation.content:
[excited] You know how everyone always calls me the party person? Like, "Oh, call Jamie, they'll know what to do"—well, [chuckle] this time it actually mattered. [pause] When Sarah's mom asked me to organize her surprise graduation party, I was—honestly, I felt this pressure, but also [animated] everyone just jumped in! My whole network, you know? The DJ from last New Year's, that caterer from the block party, [quickly] even that guy who does balloon animals from my nephew's thing—they all said yes immediately. 

[warm] And when Sarah walked in... [trailing off] 

[short pause] God, her face just—she completely broke down. [smiling speaking] Happy tears everywhere, like ugly-crying into her mom's shoulder, and I'm standing there with my stupid party hat on, [laugh] holding this ridiculous banner I made at 2 AM, and suddenly [shaky voice] I'm crying too because... [sniffle]

[very slowly] It hit me that all these years of throwing random parties, staying up planning stupid themes—it was practice for this. [pause] For making someone feel that loved. [happy] Her mom grabbed my hand and whispered "thank you," and I just... [crying while speaking] yeah, that's when I lost it completely.
